triton-datasource-image.body:
data "triton_image" "$1" {
    # name - (Optional) (string)   The name of the image
    name = ""

    # os - (Optional) (string)   The underlying operating system for the image
    os = ""

    # version - (Optional) (string)   The version for the image
    version = ""

    # public - (Optional) (boolean)   Whether to return public as well as private images
    public = ""

    # state - (Optional) (string)   The state of the image. By default, only `active` images are shown. Must be one of:   `active`, `unactivated`, `disabled`, `creating`, `failed` or `all`, though the   default is sufficient in almost every case.
    state = ""

    # owner - (Optional) (string)   The UUID of the account which owns the image
    owner = ""

    # type - (Optional) (string)   The image type. Must be one of: `zone-dataset`, `lx-dataset`, `zvol`, `docker` or   `other`.
    type = ""

    # most_recent - (Optional) (bool) If more than one result is returned, use the most recent Image.
    most_recent = ""

    # Exported Attributes
}
triton-datasource-image.description:
The `triton_image` data source queries the Triton Image API for an image ID based
on a variety of different parameters.

triton-datasource-network.description:
The `triton_network` data source queries the Triton Network API for a network ID
based on the name of the network.

triton-resource-fabric.body:
resource "triton_fabric" "$1" {
    # name - (Optional) (String, Required, Change forces new resource)   Network name.
    name = ""

    # description - (Optional) (String, Optional, Change forces new resource)   Optional description of network.
    description = ""

    # subnet - (Optional) (String, Required, Change forces new resource)   CIDR formatted string describing network.
    subnet = ""

    # provision_start_ip - (Optional) (String, Required, Change forces new resource)   First IP on the network that can be assigned.
    provision_start_ip = ""

    # provision_end_ip - (Optional) (String, Required, Change forces new resource)   Last assignable IP on the network.
    provision_end_ip = ""

    # gateway - (Optional) (String, Optional, Change forces new resource)   Optional gateway IP.
    gateway = ""

    # resolvers - (Optional) (List, Optional)   Array of IP addresses for resolvers.
    resolvers = ""

    # routes - (Optional) (Map, Optional, Change forces new resource)   Map of CIDR block to Gateway IP address.
    routes = ""

    # internet_nat - (Optional) (Bool, Optional, Change forces new resource)   If a NAT zone is provisioned at Gateway IP address. Default is `false`. This differs from [CloudAPI](https://apidocs.joyent.com/cloudapi/#CreateFabricNetwork) which implicitly creates a NAT instance by default.   NOTE: There is a known issue in Triton that prevents deletion of fabric networks when `internet_nat` is enabled.
    internet_nat = ""

    # vlan_id - (Optional) (Int, Required, Change forces new resource)   VLAN id the network is on. Number between 0-4095 indicating VLAN ID.
    vlan_id = ""

    # Exported Attributes
}
triton-resource-fabric.description: The `triton_fabric` resource represents an fabric for a Triton account. The fabric is a logical set of interconnected switches.

triton-resource-firewall-rule.body:
resource "triton_firewall_rule" "$1" {
    # rule - (Optional) (string, Required)   The firewall rule described using the Cloud API rule syntax defined at https://docs.joyent.com/public-cloud/network/firewall/cloud-firewall-rules-reference.
    rule = ""

    # enabled - (Optional) (boolean)  Default: `false`   Whether the rule should be effective.
    enabled = ""

    # Exported Attributes
}
triton-resource-firewall-rule.description: The `triton_firewall_rule` resource represents a rule for the Triton cloud firewall.

triton-resource-key.body:
resource "triton_key" "$1" {
    # name - (Optional) (string, Change forces new resource)   The name of the key. If this is left empty, the name is inferred from the comment in the SSH key material.
    name = ""

    # key - (Optional) (string, Required, Change forces new resource)   The SSH key material. In order to read this from a file, use the `file` interpolation.
    key = ""

    # Exported Attributes
}
triton-resource-key.description: The `triton_key` resource represents an SSH key for a Triton account.

triton-resource-machine.body:
resource "triton_machine" "$1" {
    # name - (Optional) (string)   The friendly name for the machine. Triton will generate a name if one is not specified.
    name = ""

    # tags - (Optional) (map)   A mapping of tags to apply to the machine.
    tags = ""

    # cns - (Optional) (map of CNS attributes, Optional)   A mapping of [CNS](https://docs.joyent.com/public-cloud/network/cns) attributes to apply to the machine.
    cns = ""

    # metadata - (Optional) (map, optional)   A mapping of metadata to apply to the machine.
    metadata = ""

    # package - (Optional) (string, Required)   The name of the package to use for provisioning.
    package = ""

    # image - (Optional) (string, Required)   The UUID of the image to provision.
    image = ""

    # networks - (Optional) (list, optional)   The list of networks to associate with the machine. The network ID will be in hex form, e.g `xxxxxxxx-xxxx-xxxx-xxxx-xxxxxxxxxxxx`.
    networks = ""

    # affinity - (Optional) (list of Affinity rules, Optional)   A list of valid [Affinity Rules](https://apidocs.joyent.com/cloudapi/#affinity-rules) to apply to the machine which assist in data center placement. Using this attribute will force resource creation to be serial. NOTE: Affinity rules are best guess and assist in placing instances across a data center. They're used at creation and not referenced after.
    affinity = ""

    # locality - (Optional) (map of Locality hints, Optional)   A mapping of [Locality](https://apidocs.joyent.com/cloudapi/#CreateMachine) attributes to apply to the machine that assist in data center placement. NOTE: Locality hints are only used at the time of machine creation and not referenced after.
    locality = ""

    # firewall_enabled - (Optional) (boolean)  Default: `false`   Whether the cloud firewall should be enabled for this machine.
    firewall_enabled = ""

    # root_authorized_keys - (Optional) (string)   The public keys authorized for root access via SSH to the machine.
    root_authorized_keys = ""

    # user_data - (Optional) (string)   Data to be copied to the machine on boot.
    user_data = ""

    # user_script - (Optional) (string)   The user script to run on boot (every boot on SmartMachines).
    user_script = ""

    # administrator_pw - (Optional) (string)   The initial password for the Administrator user. Only used for Windows virtual machines.
    administrator_pw = ""

    # cloud_config - (Optional) (string)   Cloud-init configuration for Linux brand machines, used instead of `user_data`.
    cloud_config = ""

    # Exported Attributes
}
triton-resource-machine.description:
The `triton_machine` resource represents a virtual machine or infrastructure container running in Triton. ~> **Note:** Starting with Triton 0.2.0, Please note that when you want to specify the networks that you want the machine to be attached to, use the `networks` parameter
and not the `nic` parameter.

triton-resource-vlan.body:
resource "triton_vlan" "$1" {
    # vlan_id - (Optional) (int, Required, Change forces new resource)   Number between 0-4095 indicating VLAN ID
    vlan_id = ""

    # name - (Optional) (string, Required)   Unique name to identify VLAN
    name = ""

    # description - (Optional) (string, Optional)   Description of the VLAN
    description = ""

    # Exported Attributes
}
triton-resource-vlan.description: The `triton_vlan` resource represents an Triton VLAN. A VLAN provides a low level way to segregate and subdivide the network. Traffic on one VLAN cannot, _on its own_, reach another VLAN.
